Ford Foundation gave to Johns
Hopkins a grant of $750,000 to
establish a department of social relations, which will include the fields of social theory,
cultural anthropology, social
psychology and demography.
Dr. Coleman's appointment is
the first step in implementing
this department.
Columbia Ph.D.
The new Hopkins professor
attended Emory and Henry
College, Indiana University,
and he received his bachelor's
degree in chemical engineering
from Purdue University in 1949.
In 1955, after four years of
study at Columbia University,
he was awarded his Ph.D. degree in sociology.
Dr. Coleman served as a research associate at the Bureau
of Applied Social Research at
Columbia from 1953 to 1955,
then was for one year a Fellow
of the Center for Advanced
Study in Behavioral Sciences.
Since 1956 he has been a sampling consultant for the National Opinion Research Center.
Coordinate Branch
The new Hopkins social relations department will function, not only as a unit itself,
but also as a center to coordinate the university's various
other social science departments such as political economy, history, and political
'science.
Dr. Coleman has several
significant research projects
currently underway. He is concluding a book manuscript on
the uses of mathematics in
sociology, he is studying the
analysis of social structures bythe use of electronic computers,
and he has prepared a study
of the effects of different kinds
of educational. "climates" -in.
high schools as they effect the
educational aims and aspirations of the students.
A native of Bedford, Indiana,
Dr. Coleman is married and
the father of two sons.

Lester Williams
, On June 27, 1958, Lester
Williams, an undergraduate
student at the Hopkins, died
at Johns Hopkins Hospital
after a long illness.
During his hospitalization,
doctors requested large quantities of blood for him. Hopkins students respprided with
donations totaling over forty
pints.
Speaking for the university
and Lester's family, the NewsLetter wishes to express their
sincere thanks to all those
who gave. They acted humanely and unselfishly. All
Hopkins may justly be proud
of these men, whose strong
spirit and loyalty have
brought credit upon it.

It took five men just ten minutes to accomplish what thirteen
had failed to do in three years
when the Inter-Fraternity Board
admitted Zeta Beta Tau as a
provisional member at its most
.
recent meeting.
The 5-4-1 affirmative vote
came after an ironically short
discussion period during which
IFB President Steve Broening
read an official statement from
ZBT President Mickey Levin explaining that fraternity's qualifications for membership.
"With all the criteria met, I
see no reason why this motion
(that ZBT be admitted on a
provisional basis) should not be
accepted," Broening stated after
concluding Levin's letter.
Want No Rebuke
The question of ZBT's formal
application for membership was
answered by Levin, who read a
motion previously passed by his
fraternity which stated that
group's desire to apply immediately following an affrmative
membership vote by the board.
"We want to be assured of admittance before we apply in
order that we aren't rebuked
again," Levin said.
A motion to admit zar as a
permanent member with . all
rights and privileges had been
defeated at a previous meeting
of the IFB.
Shows Responsibility
"I maintain that an affirmative vote would be a statement of
our responsibility rather than
one of permanent membership,"
Broening explained. The affirmative vote which followed included, nevertheless, an understanding that a vote for permanent membership would occur in
the future at the discretion of
the board chairman, "whenever
he feels such reconsideration is
in order."
At present ZBT's status as
provisional member gives it all
the privileges of board membership and makes it subject to all
IFB regulations and membership
fees, but denies it a vote at
meetings.
Compulsory Membership
A plan that would establish
set procedures by which any social fraternity forming at Hopkins would be admitted to the
IFB was again brought up after
it had been introduced at the
board's previous meeting.
Kappa Alpha delegate Dave
Meredith asked for suggestions
concerning his four-fold plan for
future IFB membership, which
would make any new social
group subject to approval of the
Dean of Students and would
automatically make this group a
full IFB member when its qualifications c ould be recognized
after a two-year period of provisional membership.
Obedience First
The new plan's emphasis on
"automatic membership" came
under fire when one delegate
questioned the wisdom of placing
the only actual vote of the board

upon a motion for provisional
rather than permanent membership, "since the IFB would then
have no voting power to deny
admittance to a fraternity that
had not obeyed the rules."
Broening explained that a
special committee, to include the
IFB president and Dean of Students, would review "dispassionately" the status and qualifications of a new group after its
two-year period of provisional
membership. "Provisional status,
where the fraternity can be fined
for disobeying the. rules, will
show definitely whether a fraternity has obeyed or not,"
Broening stated.
Morality Play
AEPi representative Al Jacobson expressed the feeling that
judgment on a fraternity's acceptance should be "a moral
one." He said: "It is a question
of what the IFB stands for, and
this is obviously to make rules
for its member fraternities. We
are somewhat a fraternity ourselves, and should be able to
vote to refuse or admit others
into our group. We should therefore eliminate all criteria and
view a new group as we feel."
Phi Psi delegate Lee Carter
disagreed, saying, "We are not
a big, _happy group at all—the
IFB is neither fraternal nor social. Moral judgments here are
impossible, and criteria are necessary."
